It belongs to the family Ericaceae and is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit. The plant features small, showy flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, arranged in clusters. Its foliage consists of narrow, leathery leaves that are evergreen. Oocephalus lythroides is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in well-drained, acidic soils.
